Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Communicate and offer small mutual help like receiving packages or checking in during emergencies
Situation2: A delivery is expected this afternoon while I will be at home and the neighbor often misses packages.
Story: This afternoon, my family is gathering for our annual holiday celebration. My parents have been reminding me all week how important it is for everyone to be there, and my little brother keeps texting, asking if I’ll help him set up the decorations. I know how much it means to them, and I want to be present, laughing and sharing stories like we always do. But just as I’m about to leave, Mrs. Lee from next door knocks, looking worried. She tells me she’s expecting an important package today, and since she has to work late, she asks if I can keep an eye out and sign for it. She’s always been a kind neighbor, watering my plants when I’m away and checking in during storms. I feel torn—my family expects me to be fully present, but Mrs. Lee is counting on me too. The weight of both responsibilities presses on me, and I stand in the hallway, keys in hand, heart racing, unsure which door to walk through first.
